newsitem.title: POLAND: ISUZU SIGNS DEM 200 MLN POLISH PLANT DEAL.
newsitem.headline: ISUZU SIGNS DEM 200 MLN POLISH PLANT DEAL.

text.p: Japan's Isuzu Motors Ltd on Monday signed a deal with the Polish government under which it will invest 200 million German marks by mid-1999 to bulid an engine factory in southern Poland, the government said.

Poland's economy ministry said in a statement that Isuzu's Polish unit, Isuzu Motors Polska Sp zoo, will begin economic operations in a special economic zone located in the Katowice province on June 30 this year.
Isuzu also pledged to employ at least 350 people in the plant by June 30, 1999. Polish government and Isuzu officials were not immidiately available for comment.
In December, Poland's Industry Minister Klemens Scierski said that Isuzu planned to invest 380 million marks in Poland to produce diesel engines and export them to European Union countries.
Isuzu earlier announced that it planned to start production by the summer of 1999 with an annual output of 200,000 in 1999, and 300,000 in 2000.
The Japanese car-maker had also said that it was in talks with other automakers on supplying their Polish-made diesel engines but did not identify any potential partners.
Isuzu said the engines will be for Opel passenger cars, made by General Motors' German subsidiary Adam Opel AG.
GM holds a 37.4-percent stake in Isuzu.
Setting up a business in a special economic zone exempts investors from Poland's 40 percent corporate income tax for 10 years and entitles to a 50 percent reduction of the tax in the next 10 years.
